title: Team Ineos Grenadiers to switch to disc brakes
content:
Team Ineos Grenadiers is set to switch to disc brakes for tomorrow’s Grand Prix de Denain, in a move that could signal the end of rim brakes in the professional peloton.

The British-registered WorldTour team has resolutely stuck to rim brakes despite rival teams overwhelmingly adopting road disc brakes in recent years.

However, Ineos Grenadiers riders will use the Pinarello Dogma F Disc for GP de Denain, a one-day race in northern France, and in the build-up to Paris-Roubaix on Sunday 3 October.

“Our relationship with Pinarello has always been grounded in a love of racing and innovation, and their work on the Dogma F Disc should enable our riders to race to their maximum,” said Carsten Jeppesen, the team’s head of technical partners.

“Working closely with Pinarello and Shimano, we will continue to develop the all-round disc package, optimising weight, the integration across Dura-Ace, and improvements in the quick release system,” he continued.

Team Ineos Grenadiers

While Ineos Grenadiers has offered little detail around the switch, GP de Denain is “the first race in the initial phase of the disc brake roll out for the team”, according to the press release announcing the move.

The statement also says the decision has come after close consultation with “the riders, performance team, Pinarello and Shimano”.

Pinarello launched its latest flagship bike, the Pinarello Dogma F, in June, with the disc frame kit (frame, fork, seatpost, cockpit) claimed to save 256g over the existing Dogma F12.

The development of the new Shimano Dura-Ace R9200 groupset has also largely been focused on disc brakes, though the image accompanying this latest announcement pictures the Dogma F Disc in Ineos colours with the outgoing Dura-Ace Di2 R9150 drivetrain.

While Shimano is continuing to support rim brakes at Dura-Ace level, the new R9200 rim brakes are nearly identical to the current R9100 units.

Most notably, the rim brake shifters aren’t wireless, whereas the disc brakes shifters communicate wirelessly to the rear derailleur, which is in turn wired to the front derailleur and battery.

With Shimano heavily backing disc-brake technology with its latest launch, it is perhaps little surprise to see cycling’s most powerful WorldTour team finally adopt disc brakes and, with it, Shimano’s flagship groupset.

We expect the team to switch to the new groupset imminently.

Ineos-Grenadiers’ director of racing, Rod Ellingworth, added: “Pinarello are constantly working to keep our bike at the front of the peloton and their commitment to providing us [with] the very best equipment has been evident across this project. Rider feedback has also been encouraging.”
author: George Scott
